analytic.title: The Semitic Dimension of Christian Tradition

biblStruct.note: "From what we have said it is clear that the study of Syriac East is absolutely necessary for a comprehensive outlook on Christian theology in general. The Greek and Latin theologies combined do not form the mainstream Christian vision. Both of them are younger branches of the tree of Christianity the trunk of which is semitic, Judeo-Christian, Aramaic and Syriac. So the study of Syriac language and Syriac theology is not to be an appendix. Christian theology will not be Christian unless it is Syriac, Greek and Latin. Exclusion of Syriac theology restricts Christian theology itself." (p. 75)
